notes.claim: Formal reports are relatively lengthy and their bodies contain many sections, each with its own heading or subheading for ease of reading and locating information.
notes.support: “Since a formal report is a relatively lengthy document, the body of a formal report contains many sections for ease of reading and finding specific information. ... each section in the body should have its own heading or subheading.”

notes.claim: Front matter establishes the report’s authority, intended audience, and key concepts, and includes a letter of transmittal, cover/title page, table of contents/list of figures (if needed), and an executive summary.
notes.support: “Front matter – the sections that come before the body of the report – establishes the authority of the report, intended audience, and key concepts. Front matter includes: letter of transmittal ... cover/title page ... table of contents/list of figures if needed ... executive summary – a condensed version of key ideas”

notes.claim: Include a table of contents/list of figures if the report is longer than about 5 pages and/or has many sections/figures; omit it if the report is relatively short or direct.
notes.support: “(use if a report is longer than 5 pages or so, and/or contains many different sections and figures; if the formal report is relatively short or direct, a table of contents may be omitted)”

notes.claim: The introduction sets up the report’s structure and order and reminds readers of the situation; it may also include background and the purpose/problem.
notes.support: “The introduction sets up the structure of a report. It tells your reader what is to come and in what order, and it reminds your reader of the situation that instigated the report’s creation. Sometimes the introduction contains background and purpose or problem, although these sections may also be separate”

notes.claim: The background section explains the circumstances and current situation, including constraints such as budget, time, and human resources; it can be incorporated into the introduction.
notes.support: “The background section explains the circumstances that led to the report’s creation and may explain the current situation, including any potential constraints such as budget, time, human resources, etc. In some situations, you may want to incorporate background into the introduction.”

notes.claim: A purpose or problem statement must be direct, succinct, and clear to eliminate reader uncertainty and focus attention on the report’s function and main ideas.
notes.support: “A purpose or problem statement should directly, succinctly, and clearly relay its information. The intention of a purpose or problem statement is to eliminate uncertainty or questions in your reader, so that the reader can focus immediately on the report’s function and main ideas.”

notes.claim: Each section should have a clear, descriptive heading; longer sections should use subheadings; sections should be logically grouped and classified.
notes.support: “Each section should have a clear, descriptive heading; longer sections should have subheadings; and the sections should have a logic in terms of grouping and classifying information.”

notes.claim: Example incident report body sections include: Incident; Steps Taken to Address the Situation; Environmental Analysis; Recommendations to Avoid Future Incidents.
notes.support: “example 1: incident report ... you might include the following body sections ... Incident Steps Taken to Address the Situation Environmental Analysis Recommendations to Avoid Future Incidents”

notes.claim: Example research report (event feasibility) body sections include: Location; Booths; Insurance; Personnel; Cost; Benefits; Project Management; Group Recommendations.
notes.support: “example 2: research report ... you might include some or all of the following body sections ... Location Booths Insurance Personnel Cost Benefits Project Management Group Recommendations”

notes.claim: A Research/Methods section explains how information was found, excludes the data itself (which appears later or in an appendix), and builds credibility by showing appropriate sources and expert support.
notes.support: “Research/Methods – This section explains your process of finding information; it does not contain the data itself, which comes later in the body or in an appendix, if the data is lengthy. Explaining your methodology helps establish credibility by showing that you consulted appropriate sources, and that your perspective is supported by outside experts.”

notes.claim: An Available Options/Possible Solutions section presents multiple approaches beyond the recommended one to establish credibility; it is sometimes combined with the recommendation and evaluation.
notes.support: “Available Options/Possible Solutions – This section presents multiple ways to approach a concept, process, or issue, other than the one you end up recommending. Including a comprehensive look at options also establishes your credibility ... Note that this section is sometimes combined with the recommended solution and evaluation.”

notes.claim: A Recommendation/Solution section may stand alone or be combined with evaluation; if resistance is expected, place evaluation before the recommendation; in some reports it replaces the conclusion.
notes.support: “Recommendation/Solution – This section may be a short statement of your recommendations, or it may be combined with your evaluation ... If your audience is likely to resist your recommendation, the evaluation might appear before you make the recommendation ... In some reports the recommendation is used in lieu of the conclusion.”

notes.claim: An Evaluation section prioritizes feasibility using criteria such as cost, ease of implementation, and maintenance; it should justify the recommended solution, may include graphs/charts/statistics, and should evaluate other options against the criteria.
notes.support: “Evaluation – This section details and prioritizes each option’s feasibility using criteria you develop, e.g., cost, ease of implementation, maintenance, etc. Explain how the solution you recommend is the best using these criteria; show that your solution will result in substantial benefits ... You may want to add graphs, charts, etc. ... You may want to use statistics ... If you have not yet evaluated how other solutions do not address your criteria as well, then include that evaluation here.”

notes.claim: An Implementation/Schedule section details when, why, where, and how activities occur, including expectations, dates/times, and durations; it may note observations during implementation; it’s often standard in analytical reports and can serve as how-to in informative reports.
notes.support: “Implementation/Schedule – This section details when, why, where, and how certain activities will occur. Include what is expected to happen, the date and time of implementation, the duration of implementation, etc. You may also choose to say that you will note what works and what needs to be changed during a certain implementation period. This section is often standard in analytical reports. In informative reports, it may show ‘how to’ do something.”

notes.claim: Schedules can be a separate section or part of implementation and should provide a final deadline, interim deadlines to track progress, and assurance of feasibility.
notes.support: “Note that you may opt for a separate schedule section or may include a schedule within an implementation section. Schedules provide readers with three things: 1) a final deadline ... 2) interim deadlines, which are also a way to track progress, and 3) assurance of feasibility.”

notes.claim: A Personnel/Qualifications section identifies team members, their tasks and responsibilities, and why each is appropriate based on talent and experience.
notes.support: “Personnel/Qualifications – This section identifies the people involved in a project, team, or investigation. You may explain what their tasks and responsibilities are, and show why each member is appropriate for the task, based on talent and experience.”

notes.claim: Place the Costs section toward the end; costs should be as accurate as possible, with projected costs clearly labeled as approximate; detail level varies by audience and purpose; use simple, aligned tables or spreadsheets for detailed costs.
notes.support: “Costs – This section generally occurs toward the end of the body ... Costs should be as accurate as possible; if you are projecting costs, then make it clear that they are approximate costs. Depending on your purpose, audience, and other communication variables, you may be more or less detailed ... When you need to include detailed costs, present them using tables, tabs, or spreadsheet inserts to align the amounts – simple formatting is the best.”

notes.claim: The conclusion summarizes the report’s major ideas, is not the same as an executive summary, and must not introduce new facts or ideas.
notes.support: “The conclusion finishes the body of the report by summarizing the major ideas of the report. While not the same as an executive summary, it has a similar feel ... A conclusion should never introduce a fact or idea not presented earlier in the report.”

notes.claim: Back matter can include documentation, a glossary, an appendix, or other additions to clarify sources used in the body; it varies by context and may be omitted.
notes.support: “Back matter contains documentation, a glossary, an appendix, or any other appropriate, additional information that helps clarify the sources of information used in the body of the report. ... Back matter will change depending on the context of the report, and some reports may not contain any back matter.”

notes.claim: Use appendices to serve different audiences when detailed data would overwhelm a primary audience but is valuable to a secondary audience.
notes.support: “You may choose to include the data in an appendix to meet the needs of both of your audiences.”

notes.claim: Required formatting takes precedence over standard practice; for example, in an RFP response, include the RFP at the start and move the executive summary before the title page if that is required.
notes.support: “this proposal was written in response to a request for proposals (RFP), so the author decided to include a copy of the RFP at the start. ... to follow the format required in the RFP, the writer moved the executive summary before the title page ... since required format always take precedence over standard practice.”

notes.claim: Position recommendations/conclusions based on anticipated audience reaction: near the start for neutral/positive audiences and toward the end for negative audiences.
notes.support: “if your audience is expected to react neutrally or positively to your message, then your conclusion or recommendation might be offered near the beginning of the report. If your audience is expected to react negatively to your message, ... place the conclusion or recommendation toward the end of the report.”

notes.claim: Create, name, and order body sections based on purpose, context, and audience needs, making conscious choices grounded in situational analysis.
notes.support: “you usually have the ability to create, name, and order sections in the body of the report according to your purpose, context, and audience’s needs. ... make sure that they result from your conscious choice, based on your situational analysis of the communication situation for the formal report.”

notes.claim: An executive summary is a condensed version of the report’s key ideas.
notes.support: “executive summary – a condensed version of key ideas”

notes.claim: A letter of transmittal introduces the report to its audience.
notes.support: “letter of transmittal – to introduce the report to its audience”
